text: I ordered the minced pork noodles (bak chor mee) ‚Äúplain‚Äù version (i.e. neither having any chilli nor tomato ketchup) and it tasted quite good. I liked how they mixed the oil (most likely lard), soy sauce, white pepper, and other condiments. The taste was quite balanced when I compared with other stalls I had the ‚Äúplain‚Äùbak chor mee before. The only thing that wasn‚Äôt really to my taste was the type of noodles that they used. I think it‚Äôs a bit sticky. It could be due to overcooked accidentally. For a simple dish at a neighbourhood hawker centre and the price is less than $5, I won‚Äôt ask for more üòÑ

Decent BCM at only $4. Noodle portion pretty big for its price but the ingredients miserable, some mushroom slices, spoonful of minced meats, one meatball & one fried wanton, that's it! They should consider 2-tier pricing for the big eaters.

A perennial favourite. Heng Heng's BCM has been consistent over the years. Have a soft spot for their dry kway teow/bee hoon with their distinctive chilli. Unlike other stalls, the owners have resisted against price increases while maintaining similar portions.
Deliciously light breakfast Heng Heng Noodles.  This stall operates from 6.30am to 2pm.
is refreshing type of ba cho mee, not sticky, heavy type.
